comment: I don't mind dry whiskeys with bite, but the booze is overpowering in this one.

Unlike many of the so-called small batch ryes that are really made from a factory in Indiana, this is the real deal. Very clean, very smooth and it is genuine small batch. I cannot recommend this enough!
Aged in port casks. has a fruity taste and no after-bite.
I was greatly disappointed.  This rye is flowery.  Maintains a very poor sweet after taste.  Not a good rye at all.  I drank half the bottle and poured the rest down the drain.
Fairly standard rye whiskey.  Lovely rye spice and rye bread on the nose. A fair amount of bite in the mouth.
An unusual herbal-grassy nose and flavor until the rye rears up and bites you. This one is best with water or ice added.

Good rye for the cost. Some sweet notes and a good burn. I think this rye is young but aging their whiskey in quarter barrels allows them to produce a good product in a shorter amount of time. I am excited to see what Dad's Hat releases in the future. If you're in the Philadelphia area this is a fun distillery to visit.
I wanted to like this, but couldn't.
nose of rye immediate citrus notes on the first taste. slight cherry and caramel

As others have said, definitely a light fruity, floral twist here. Unmistakable rye backbone though. Definitely something different for rye lovers. Hey... you don't want every rye you taste to taste like every other rye!
Spicy rye with leather and tobacco.

Dads Hat Pennsylvania Rye whiskey is an attempt to recreate the Rye whiskey style that was distilled in Pennsylvania before Washington (the President that is) put down the Whiskey Rebellion in 1794. This Pennsylvania or Monongahela style Rye is America's first indigenous distilled spirit. A great article about the history of Americas Rye whiskey can be found at https://www.thedailybeast.com/how-pennsylvania-rye-whiskey-lost-its-way

But on to the tasting. This whiskey is bottled at 45% ABV. Dads Hat is made from a mash bill of 80% Rye/5% malted Rye/15% malted barley. NO CORN!! This lack of corn is apparent in the palate of this dram: there is little to no sweetness. It is a medium/dark amber in the glass. It produces a thick oily coating on the glass, only grudgingly giving up some long legs. There is no age statement beyond "minimum 6 months". It is reported that Dads Hat uses 15 gallon casks for aging, resulting in significantly faster aging. It is evident in the tasting of this dram; it comes off as more like a 3-4 yr old. 

The nose of this whiskey is RYE! Like Rye bread with dark honey. There is orange marmalade, the bitter kind with Seville oranges. Hints of cherry cough syrup. Also a very slight alcohol burn with some oak char. 

The palate is very different: woody, spicy, leather, malted cereal. There is little to no sweetness. None of the typical bourbon flavors of vanilla and caramel. It has an oily mouthfeel. Water enhances the malty/cereal tones. 

The finish is a little hot at first with a dry oak spice flavor lingering. This is a truly different whiskey. It has little to nothing in common with most of the ryes you find on the shelf of your local liquor store. It runs $45-50 online. I don't know if I would keep this bottle as a staple, but it is definitely worth trying as a testament to the history of American spirits. Solid 4.0/5. Cheers!

For rye lovers. The nose shows sweet cherry, Mexican vanilla, orange spice. The first taste hits with a little wood, a sharp edge, perhaps some faint cherry, followed by green peppercorns. No corn sweetness nor butter here. Finish is dry and strong, with lingering semi-bitter dark chocolate, grassiness, dry leaves, and the rye alcohol burn.
Spicy but without the bite.  Smoother than the previous eyes I have tried.  Interesting and it really opens up with water.
3.6. Enjoyed but a little too sweet. After a day or two after opening the bottle, I think it got better.
I thought I was drinking a pastrami sandwich. So much rye, delicious.
Perfect for old fashioneds and Manhattans

First time having a no corn rye... definitely different for me. If you’re looking for sweetness, you won’t find it with this. Tried it neat and then added a couple drops of water, it’s a reminiscent of a single malt but with more spice. I might like it more by the time I get to the end of the bottle.
Very unusual flavor. I think it tastes like whiskey that went bad. I'm sure there is someone it there who will like this, but I have no idea who that would be.
cherry and orange hard candies, herbal/mint/menthol, sweet caramel, really dry finish
Light for a rye.  Also a Roger Wilco barrel

Only serious rye fans need apply here. High rye ryes aged less than a year have a very distinctive flavor and this one has it in abundance. Think of a young Lot 40. Even at 90 proof, there’s still a ton of flavor going on. 

For my NC friends, Dad’s Hat isn’t available in our ABC system so go out and get a bottle of Doc Porter Rye. It’s made in a similar way and has a very similar flavor.
Rye spice with a sweet, cherry/fruit finish

Nose: citrus, vanilla, sugar
Flavor: pepper, green (young) apple, cinnamon, and a long finish
Meh. Not terrible but I won’t buy a bottle either.
My cousin came into town for a weekend. Picked this up on a whim for us since we're both whiskey drinkers. Was disappointed. The flavor was lacking and a terrible burn.

You've been making your way across the visitor center compound, and see a velociraptor walking along with the bartender's arm in its mouth. Somehow this bottle is still clenched by the bartender's hand.

Plenty of rye spice on the nose, but also some orange. Rye bread, leather, some oak, and a noticeable earthy taste. It's very heat forward that fades almost completely by mid palate.

It's not bad, but save yourself the stress of having to play tug of war with that velociraptor. It's not worth trying to save that bottle.

Lovely golden brown amber color. Fruity and flowery nose. Initial taste is tobacco and leather. Then the rye spiciness takes over. Absolutely reminds me of Balcones malt whiskeys, except it has a bit of a clay finish

Nose is lightly fruity, honey sweetness, and heavy spice.

Taste is heavy spice and rye, very little sweetness, dry, but still smooth

Finish long, smooth, rye.

A standout and affordable rye
Surprisingly smooth! It smells and taste like a typical oaky bourbon, but it goes down like water. Definitely easy to lose track of how much you've had
